author: leonardder
body:
# Prerequisites
This can be reproduced with a domain account with the active directory powershell module installed.

# Steps to reproduce
1. Get the following project: [PowerShellTest.zip](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/4275863/PowerShellTest.zip)
2. In program.cs, enter proper username, domain and password.
3. Execute the program

# Expected behavior
The AD server hostname is returned: "AD33.aspect.local" in my case.

# Actual behavior
I'm getting the following error: 
`Unable to contact the server. This may be because this server does not exist, it is currently down, or it does not have the Active Directory Web Services running.`

# Environment data
```
PSVersion                      7.0.0-rc.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0-rc.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
I'm not particularly familiar with the approach here, but the symptom looks very similar to the classic [double-hop problem](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/learn/remoting/ps-remoting-second-hop?view=powershell-7) often encountered in PowerShell.

Because the Active Directory commands tend to reach out to a remote machine (typically the domain controller) as part of their normal routine, you can run into issues when trying to do things like this...

Essentially, any process running under a specified credential cannot use that same credential implicitly when it reaches out to a secondary server. You have to explicitly supply that same credential in order to reuse it. In the case of Active Directory cmdlets, this is done by passing a PSCredential object to their `-Credential` parameter.

I believe this restriction applies in all remoting and impersonation scenarios using typical Windows APIs, not just PowerShell.
